title: Oh my Godfather!
content:
I don't know how I had not watched this film until just a week ago, but I'm glad because this is not a movie to watch with distractions or when you are too young because you will not enjoy it as much as an adult does. I saw this movie and immediately become an addict, watched it at least 3 more times the same week. There is so much to talk about it! I found it hard to think someone doesn't enjoying this one. The cast, the great dialogue, big plot twists, all the emotions, everything makes it just great. This is no a film as many of these times that need a 4K quality to be appealing, you will not waste your time, every minute of the almost 3 hours is worth. You will want even more.
If you haven't watch it, what are you waiting for? ("This is an offer you can't refuse")

title: The Godfather
content: This movie is a Piece of Art in every aspect. At first it didn't really catch my eye but it didn't take a lot of time for me to realize that this movie is one of the greatest ever made. And yes, it does not have any flaws. Tho some people say it's too long, I really think it's actually too short, if could've watched this for at least another hour. Character building in one movie is actually a very tough thing to do right but in this movie Michael's character development is one of if the the greatest I have ever seen. Now after all of that does The Godfather Deserve a perfect 10? I believe so. If you didn't watch it yet, it's time.

title: Classic.
content: The Godfather is without a doubt one of the greatest films ever made.  It combines a superb plot, excellent acting, and top-drawer directing. Brando is great.  Pacino is at his best.  Add Robert Duvall, James Caan, Diane Keaton, and Talia Shire in spectacular performances and you have a terrific ensemble cast. The plot, which combines a mob story with the moving story of a family -their lives, loves, and loyalties- is brilliantly written.  It can definitely be called the greatest film ever made.

title: Absolutely perfect
content: Whether you're an admirer of the genre or not, Mafia films have no better ally than The Godfather in defining what you expect from such a tragic and dramatic subject. This masterpiece doesn't just tell the story of killings and score-settling, it instils in its viewers values and ways of life that are benevolent and just a few steps away from the reasonable and respectable. As well as mixing several generations of absolutely titanic actors, the story behind the madness engendered by the thirst for power and money shows us that without love, family and friends, man will never be happy or fulfilled.A fine lesson in education and principles, more than a film, a philosophy.

title: Simply the best film ever made
content: It's kinda hard to describe this movie. After watching it, every other movie that I have seen just feels... I don't know... weak. Inferior. Fake.The incredible performances in this film make it feel real. The story is awesome. It's tense when it needs to be tense, sad when it needs to be sad, and it makes you feel for the characters, who are written brilliantly.I can't say anything more than that you need to see this movie. An epic masterpiece. 10/10.

title: Title: A Timeless Masterpiece - The Godfather
content: Title: A Timeless Masterpiece - The Godfather"The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola and released in 1972, is a cinematic gem that continues to stand the test of time. This iconic film not only redefined the crime genre but also set a new standard for storytelling and character development in the world of cinema.The story revolves around the Corleone family, led by the enigmatic patriarch, Vito Corleone, portrayed brilliantly by Marlon Brando. Brando's performance is nothing short of legendary, as he effortlessly embodies the complex character of the mafia boss with a sense of authority and vulnerability that is unparalleled.Al Pacino, in one of his career-defining roles, plays Michael Corleone, the youngest son who becomes entangled in the family's criminal empire. Watching his transformation from an innocent young man to a ruthless and calculating mobster is both captivating and chilling.The supporting cast, including James Caan, Robert Duvall, and Diane Keaton, all deliver exceptional performances that add depth and authenticity to the narrative. The chemistry and dynamics among the characters are palpable, making the audience emotionally invested in their fates.Coppola's direction is nothing short of perfection, creating an atmosphere that immerses viewers in the world of organized crime. The film's cinematography, with its evocative lighting and meticulous attention to detail, adds to the overall ambiance of tension and power struggles.The Godfather's screenplay, adapted from Mario Puzo's novel, is a masterclass in storytelling. It explores themes of family, loyalty, power, and corruption in a way that transcends its genre. The dialogue is iconic, and many lines from the film have become part of cinematic history.Nino Rota's hauntingly beautiful score enhances the film's emotional impact, creating a sense of melancholy that lingers long after the credits roll.In summary, "The Godfather" is a cinematic treasure that has left an indelible mark on the film industry. It's a must-see for anyone who appreciates storytelling at its finest, masterful performances, and a gripping narrative that explores the depths of human nature. It remains a timeless classic and deserves its place among the greatest films ever made.

title: My #4 favorite film of all time (including part 2)
content: What more could be said about the Godfather (1+2). The legacy of mafia crime family dramas begins and ends here. The lines of dialogue have been forever embedded into the American culture and film discourse. Pacino, Brando, Dinero, Keaton, Caan, and the whole cast fit the bill with impeccable conviction.The morals and themes of the pictures have such a profound impact unlike any preceding film. It empathizes with a traditionally antagonistic side of society and shows its varying dimensions. Men who steal, rob, and murder do so for reasons other than their own personal self-indulgence. They believe 'the life' is for the greatest benefit for their family, but then take it too far.Films up to this point had a narrow view of the motivation of the accomplices in organized crime. The Godfathers enlightened the film going public about the motivations of the mafia, crime and crime families but doesn't defend it. It merely observes the chosen and or inherit ethics of life in the crime family.

title: Great movie but better the second time around.
content: I had heard so much hype surrounding the Godfather movies but I had never seen them. I finally decided to sit down and watch the Godfather. Maybe my expectations were way too high before I watched it because everyone was regarding this as the greatest movie ever made. When I sat down to watch it, during the first hour I was bored out of my mind. It put me to sleep and I cut it off and decided to watch it later. A few days later I decided to watch the rest of the movie and started to realize the movie's greatness.If you get past the first hour the movie is highly entertaining with great dialog and great acting. Al Pacino is one of the greatest actors in American History in my opinion.Watching the movie the second time made me realize that this is probably one of he greatest movies ever. The character development is excellent and you understand that more upon the second viewing.In summary, if you haven't seen this movie don't expect to be blown away the first time watching. Let the movie develop and when the movie ends you will want to watch it again from the beginning to understand everything that happened. After that you would be hard pressed to deny this movie as one of the greatest.

title: Classic film
content: The opening shot of "The Godfather" sets the tone of the film as Don Corleone and some of his family listen to an undertaker, Amerigo Bonasera (Salvatore Cirsitto), pleading for justice for the near-rape and brutal beating suffered by his daughter...Attending the wedding of his sister Connie to young bookmaker Carlo Rizzi, Michael, a highly decorated Marine captain from World War II, points out the other guests to Kate (Diane Keaton), his non-Italian girlfriend... In the same time Coppola introduces us to his large cast of characters:Sonny (James Caan), the rough, hot-headed impulsive kid who never really grew up; Fredo (John Cazale), the troubled, shy, weak young man who can't seem to do anything right; Tom (Robert Duvall), the right-hand man, the legal adviser and adopted son to the Godfather- steady, reliable, always thinking, always controlled; Connie (Talia Shire), the battered wife and rebellious sister, who achieves and promotes the movie's most horrific scene; Johnny Fontane (Al Martine), the idol star whose tears set up the shocking moment when a movie "big shot" named Jack Woltz (John Marley) finds himself in an horrifying pool of blood; Luca Brasi (Lenny Montana), the giant criminal thug, one of Corleone's most trusted enforcers; Tessio (Abbe Vigoda), the fearsome tall enforcer who implies the possibility of violent revenge guaranteeing Michael's safety; and Clemenza (Richard Castellano), the other faithful enforcer...

title: I don't get it
content: OK, I REALLY don't get it. I always thought: "Oh well, the Godfather, masterpiece, everyone has to watch it at least once in their live, let's see it then (someday)". Then today I finally decided myself to watch it and I was shocked about it.To make it short, it was boring, WAY to long for the amount of real action (and I don't mean Micheal bay action, I mean something like a traceable storyline that doesn't introduce new names and character every time something really happens (and thats not often the case) so that in the end, you don't even know who's who and what is really happening. I don't like a film where you don't know who is doing the action you see, especially if some of the main characters are so similar that you can't distinguish them in some scenes. Also, the film is too long. Take the first set for example, the wedding (or was it a wedding?). If you count all the minutes you see some macaroni's dancing without sense or entertaining the viewer, I think it's around 5 to 10mins. If you look at that you know why the movie is around 3 hours long. Coming to the characters, I didn't have any emotional relationship to them after 3 hours of nearly non-stop conversation. I didn't really care when they died, first because in most cases, I didn't know who was killed in the scene most times and second, because I had no emotions for them. (Let's take that scene near the end, where all the people get killed, like 5 or 6 in three different locations. I didn't even recognize one of them, the whole scene didn't make sense for me. Why would they shoot a women with their child in the bed, especially if the viewer doesn't know who (the f**k) she is??? Not really a pro for a so-called "masterpiece") The only two pros I have are the acting and the music. I have to say I'm not a pro in commenting acting in films (watched Catwoman and didn't have a clue why Halle Berry became the golden raspberry for their acting after learning all that stuff with the walking like a cat, martial arts etc.). But I have to say what I've seen in this film is the most natural acting possible. None of the scenes looks contrived, the "we are all family" part came very good. Also the soundtrack is really worth recognizing.To sum it up:Acting: 10/10 Storyline: 4/10 (really disappointing) Action: 3/10 (even more disappointing) Lenght: 2/10 Soundtrack: 8/10Overall: Around 4-5/10, I'll give it 4 because it's overrated.PS: I watched "The Rock" the same day and found it much better than "The Godfather" (Better action, no lenghts, even better soundtrack, a very simple but at least traceable story)

title: Godfather is to cinema what Bill Gates is to money
content: Without the Godfather cinema is missing its backbone.  Often heralded as the greatest movie in history, I would not dare disagree.  This is the only flawless material this world has ever made.  The script could not be better even if Shakespeare wrote it.  The direction could not be better if Spielberg directed it.  The acting could not be better if a gun was held up to the head of each actor.  Marlon Brando gives the single greatest performance by an actor this millenium, winning the best actor oscar hands down.  It just goes to show the entire world no actor has ever been better (On the Waterfront, A Streetcar Named Desire, Viva Zapata...)  Al Pacino was also stunning in his early career and showed signs of becoming the best actor of his generation (which he is, just barely ahead of De Niro and Hoffman).  James Caan and Robert Duvall also put in stellar performances which garnered oscar nominations for them both.  The Godfather should be studied in school to show what the partnership of perfection and complete mastery can do for a picture.  This movie is not at all matched by it's sequel or any other movie for that matter.  I would give my left arm to go see it on theater (c'mon i can't give my right arm i need that to press play and watch it at home).  No accomplishment by Da Vinci in innovation or Van Gogh in art can match what the Godfather has done for cinema.  Nearly number one on every single famous list in the world its an inspiration.  Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) shows such insight and power in leading a family I wouldn't mind letting him run America as President.  I own three copies of this movie one for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  I recommend this movie for anyone who can breathe.  rating/10.  PS contact me for any more recommendations on movies, they don't call me the "tree of knowledge" for nothing.

title: Such a classic
content: The Godfather follows Vito Corleone, the titular character, sinisterly played by Marlon Brando, as he tries to develop his son, Michael (a young and excellent Al Pacino) to become the 'Don' of the Corleone family, albeit in a violent and dangerous, Mafia dominating New York.The first thing that I noticed was the lighting. I thought that it perfectly encapsulated the two natures of the Corleone family: the terrifying and ruthless yet fiercely family orientated. Corleone is constantly in the shadow, while also being in the light, and it highlights the two sided nature of him.The next amazing thing about this is the acting. Brando nails the mysteriously dangerous family man who is feared and respected in equal manner. Al Pacino is amazing and nails the arc of war hero, innocent and loved, to Brando's protege, as he turns into the evil Don. The supporting actors of James Caan, Diane Keaton and Robert Duvall get a good showing, perfectly supporting the two main ones (Al Pacino should have got leading actor!)The score and editing creates this beautiful Italian set piece, and it's stunning.

title: One of the best movies in history!
content: Unfortunately, today we can no longer watch such quality movies. This film is powerful, a good script, an excellent casting, an excellent acting and a top direction. It's hard to fine a film made so well, it's 29 years old and it's aged well. Even if the viewer does not like mobster movies, he or she will watch the entire movie, the audience is glued to what will happen next as the movie progresses. It's about family, loyalty, greed, relationships and real life. This is a great mix, and the artistic style makes the film memorable.

title: The best movie when i ever watched
content: The head of the Mafia clan, Vito Corleone, marries off his daughter Connie. Just in time for the wedding, Don Vito's youngest son Michael returns from the war. He has fought heroically and returned home with the firm conviction not to continue his father's business, but to do honest business. Don Corleone and his clan grow richer and more influential every year, which naturally displeases other members of the New York underworld. By cunning manipulations and intrigues, Carleone's enemies first kill one of Vito's men, and then make an attempt on the Don himself. Michael vows to save his father and declares war on the criminal gangs.Italian by birth, but American by birth, Francis Ford Copolla had already won an Oscar before The Godfather, but as a screenwriter. The first part of the gangster saga brought him real fame, as it won three Oscars upon its release, and was acknowledged as an important film work in the US and throughout the world.In 1969, a book by Mario Puzo, The Godfather, was published, making a lot of noise and becoming a national bestseller. The book tells the story of the harsh laws in the world of Italian mafiosi, of which many Americans did not even know. Two years later, because of his poverty, Puso sold the screen rights to the 33-year-old Copolla. The young director dared to make such a difficult film by inviting Hollywood icon Marlon Brando to the lead role. The second main role, he asked actors such as Robert De Niro, Martin Sheen and Robert Redford, but Copolla refused all, inviting this role to an unknown actor Al Pacino, whom he noticed in the film "Panic in Needle Park. The role immediately earned Pacino an Oscar nomination, which, however, he ignored.The phenomenon of the popularity of such a violent film lies in the fact that Copolla, using tough artistic techniques, showed the true value of family. The director succeeded in revealing the drama of the picture, which lies in the tragedy of a war hero and a very honest young man, Michael, who had to transcend his own beliefs under the pressure of responsibility and family interests. His transformation from a simple boy to a violent mobster is one of the most skilful metamorphoses in world cinema.

title: Acting powerhouse
content: As a young cinephile I am amazed that there is a movie like this one.Never seen such amazing acting done by Legend Marlon Brando 🔥🔥🔥🔥.My favourite is Al Pacino⚡⚡⚡ as Michael Corleone.That transformation from a simpleton to a beast💟💟💟💟

A masterpiece great storyline wonderful acting it's as if you forget where you are and what's currently going on in life as you get last in this epic tale of the corleone family one of the best crime films I've ever watched , the entire cast did amazing and Marlon Brando was phenomenal James caan was convincing and Al Pacino was the icing on the cake . title: Award Winning Movie
content: Watched it and I must say it had a very different story and marvelous dialogues that can create an impact.

title: Didn't get it!
content: Call me crazy, call me whatever, but I simply didn't get the movie. I think I know the reason why. After seeing 1000s of rip-offs and the motives inside this movie explored to the death in countless movies since the 70s, the initial hand-kissing scene looks pretty trite. Or the making an offer you can't refuse? Puhleeze!The movie is quite slow. I know it is all about the atmosphere, but it really is nothing special. Neither does the mumbling of Marlon Brando convey any special significance to me. Yes, he is remorseful for being a powerful leader of a criminal empire and assigning this fate to his son. Boo hoo hoo. If you don't become a crook you don't have these kinds of problems. And yes, we all get it. The aggressive son is doomed to be killed in retaliation, the ineffectual son is doomed to remain in the shadows and the resourceful son is destined to take over the "family business". He simply kills off his adversaries without it ever being made clear how he outsmarted them or why no one ever came for him in a similar fashion. He actually turns into quite a ruthless son-of-a-...But there is something more fundamental about why the movie isn't "doing anything" for me. The entire notion of "honor" and "chivalry" among criminals. It's completely fake. Now that America is mostly out of the grip of such people (not so in my own country I'm afraid, but still far from Chicago of the 20s) glorifying them is easy. The truth however is quite different. Criminals usually talk of honor, but their actions are based on much baser things. And they always have an excuse for why they ended up being crooks. Don't get suckered into believing movies like these convey any truth.Rating 5/10Scale: 10 MASTERPIECE, 9 Excellent, 8 Good, 7 OK, 6 Adequate, 5 Average, 4 Mediocre, 3 Poor, 2 Bad, 1 HORRIBLE

title: "The Godfather stands as a pinnacle of cinematic achievement, a masterclass in filmmaking that undoubtedly contends for the title of the best film of all time. In my view, it
content: Despite its nearly three-hour runtime, there's no need to fret about the duration. The movie effortlessly captures your attention, making time seem to fly by.The production values are nothing short of extraordinary; the film exudes visual splendor from start to finish, putting many contemporary films to shame despite being roughly half a century old.The performances by actors like Brandon, Pacino, and Castellano are nothing short of incredible, and there are countless other outstanding portrayals throughout the movie.For those contemplating a purchase, I highly recommend the Blu-ray version over the DVD. The visual clarity and sharpness make a noticeable difference, enhancing the viewing experience.The Godfather's profound influence over the years is undeniable, ensuring its everlasting legacy as one of the greatest films ever made. A perfect 10/10 rating is well-deserved."

title: The Van Gogh equivalent of films
content: I have had a distinct pleasure to have watched this picture for the first time in a 35mm screen this year in a cinema in London that shows classic films. I refrained from watching it years ago in my teenage years because my ignorant past thought this film was overrated, but honestly, there is no possible word or expression that can describe how wrong I was. The cinematography of this picture is so unheard of and monumental that every frame of this picture looks like something that could be hung as a painting in a museum. The story brings with it elements of something that came out of a Shakespearean Tragedy. I have watched it 7 times or more in a short time, and it takes A LOT to make me watch a film for a second time, let alone 7. It is one of, if not my favorite film of all time. If human civilization were to go extinct, this should be one of the few pieces of art that must survive for future intelligent lifeforms to discover and marvel at.

title: My review
content: Til today, I haven't bothered to review "The Godfather". After all, everyone pretty much knows it's one of the greatest films ever made. It's #2 on IMDb's Top 100. It won the Best Picture Oscar. And, there are nearly 1600 reviews on IMDb. So what's one more review?! Well, after completing 14,000 reviews (because I am nuts), I guess it's time I got around to reviewing a film I should have reviewed a long time ago. So, here goes....the film is perfect and only a dope wouldn't watch it. Unfortunately, IMDb requires me to say more to meet it's 10 line minimum for reviews. So, I'll point out that you do NOT need to like gangster films to enjoy this film. Yes, it's violent and nasty in spots--but it's also brilliantly written and produced from start to finish and deserves the accolades it's received.My advice is that instead of just watching "The Godfather" and "The Godfather: Part II", see the combined version they created for television--with additional scenes that made it a very rich experience.

title: Its fine
content: I was interested in one of the most highly reviewed movies of all time and I was not super disappointed but also not super impressed.Most of the characters are good even though I think there are way too many and the movie should have focused on fewer but more extensively. The acting of the main characters was great but there were many performances on the side which almost made me laugh (at scenes which should not be funny). The cinematography is good. Overall I would say it is a fine movie but I will probably not watch it again soon. Though I liked the ending which pulled all of the stories together.I feel like many people only remember: I'll make him an offer he can't refuse; and think it is the most iconic thing in a movie that ever happened.

title: An absolute classic

title: Great
content: I was born in 2000 so when I hear about old classic movies such as this one, I'm always scared that it will not hold up for a modern audience, that it might be too slow or outdated or etc.Let me tell you that this movie holds up, even in 2024, when I watched this for the first time. The acting work is phenomenal. Cinemotography is outstanding and the writing is really good as well. As a young person, I can recognize a lot of pop-culture references that I now know to originate from this movie. That was really fun and eye opening to see. The reason that I will not give this a 10 is because of a few moments in this movie where the plot does movie quite slow.

title: A somewhat reluctant 10 star movie
content: This is one of the hardest movies for me to evaluate because parts of it are as good as movies get and in other parts it is almost painfully boring.The best part of the movie are the two main characters (Vito and Michael). It's tough to imagine any other actors doing as well as Brando and Pacino, especially Pacino in by far his best role and performance. The story is quite good, but mostly serves as a platform to show how impressive these two characters are. The movie starts off great and has a very satisfying ending. It has also aged pretty well. A lot of older movies eventually get done better, but I don't think that's the case with this one. It does feel a bit old and if you aren't used to that, it might not work for you. To be clear, I'm not giving it points for how good it must have been to audiences when it came out, but rather judging it by today's standards. And it holds up in my opinion.The worst part of the movie is that there is about 40 minutes starting around the midpoint of the movie which is very slow and boring. It's not horrendous or anything, but hardly any other of my 10 star rated movies (about 65 total movies and I've seen a lot of movies) have such an extended boring part to it where very little happens and it's quite uninteresting (to me anyway). This boring section is somewhat useful to the plot and it wouldn't necessarily have been easy to just cut out, but it could have been a lot better. The negative impact of this section is compounded by the fact that it is a very long slow boring section in an otherwise very long slow but interesting, engaging, and excellent movie.I chose to give this a low end 10 (or 9.5 if such a rating existed here) because there is so much good in it and if you stick with the weaker parts, you do get rewarded in the end.

title: For me, 'The Godfather' will always be the greatest, dominant Mafia Epic of all time
content: "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse."Mario Puzo's 'The Godfather' is an epic, masterpiece. I mean it IS a forever classic! 'The Godfather' has influenced various films of today, like 'The Departed' and 'Smoking Aces'. Don Vito Corleone represents the true qualities of becoming one of the most established, respected figures in society's minds.Just after the release of the 1972 epic (which achieved 10 Academy Award Nominations and was named Best Picture), all "gangster films" were being judged by the style and look of this one, in particular. The strong performances, the director's unique technique and an excellent script, I believe, all play a role in 'The Godfather's' success worldwide.Italian-American director, Francis Ford Coppola introduces every major protagonist with a distinctive, complex individuality. Take Corleone for example, played by Marlon Brando. To me personally, he is seen as the most complicated gangster. He is not a killer, nor does he ever mix business with personal issues. He puts family first and doesn't like any weak people. Brando's performance as Don Corleone won him an Oscar and acknowledged him as one of America's greatest film actors.All men can relate to and understand Corleone's responsibilities of power he permanently has in his family, and how he juggles life as a father figure as well as remaining the boss of his inherited family business.The film opens on the wedding of Corleone's daughter, Connie (Talia Shire). The wedding scene is a rather good indication, of how the Don's power expands over everyone in his world, from a regular next door neighbour to a killer. His son Michael (Pacino) has just arrived back from the war, in time to see his sister's wedding. Michael is portrayed as the younger, mature and quiet gentleman of the Corleone family. Given the chance as a husband, to take care of his wife, Kay (Keaton), he doesn't intend to become a part of his family's business and just wants to live a normal life. However, being the oldest in his family, gives Michael more responsibilities, which undoubtedly he can't escape from. Being a part of a big family, running a family business, enables Michael to have more family connections. The mise-en-scene and the cinematography are more dark and realistic. Even the sepia tinged colours are reminiscent of the year it is set in. In most Gangster films, the colour black is portrayed as being highly significant and is effectively manipulated in this case. For example; Corleone's main meeting/office room, where he makes all of his decisions: by having Corleone slightly hidden in pitch-black darkness, Coppola immediately creates that sense of enigma, sinister and chilling characteristics to Brando's Corleone.Francis Ford Coppola's themes in 'The Godfather' include family responsibilities, father's inheritance, the need to earn respect and the influence of power.'The Godfather' is ideally aimed at a wide audience, except children of course; frequent Mafia violence for males, to a light-hearted, romantic tale between couples, for the females. The film effectively plays on the psychological mind, human feelings and emotions, which audiences can still accept and relate to, today.In comparison to other gangster genres, it was the first to introduce the gangster trilogy, with the film's continuous complex narrative that differentiates the importance of family. The representation of Italian ethnicity in 'The Godfather' was also new and innovative, under the conventions of a gangster film.I enjoyed watching this film in particular as well as the others in the three-part gangster saga. The Corleone family story seems so uninterrupted, if watched all together, in one go. I just love how the dialogue, comes out of the characters' mouths so truthfully. I even feel that as a whole, 'The Godfather' proves to be the greatest trilogy in cinema history.I'd have to say with pure, 100% Method Acting performances from both Brando and Pacino; this has got to be on the list of must-see films, without a doubt!

title: A Masterclass
content: The rythm is amazing, the music is amazing, everything is amazing, it's a masterclass.One of the first movies that gave transported me in through time and space to submerge me in the universe created by Francis Ford Coppola.

title: BEST MOVIE OF ALL TIME
content: "The Godfather," directed by Francis Ford Coppola and released in 1972, is a cinematic masterpiece that has stood the test of time as one of the greatest films in the history of cinema. Adapted from Mario Puzo's novel of the same name, the film is a compelling and intricate portrayal of the Corleone crime family and their patriarch, Vito Corleone, played by the iconic Marlon Brando.At its core, "The Godfather" is a story about power, family, and the consequences of a life immersed in organized crime. The film opens with a lavish wedding, setting the stage for a narrative that unfolds over a span of years. Vito Corleone, the head of the family, is a complex character whose presence commands the screen. Brando's performance is nothing short of legendary, and his portrayal of the Godfather earned him an Academy Award for Best Actor.The cinematography by Gordon Willis is a visual feast, with its dark and moody tones perfectly complementing the somber themes of the narrative. The film's iconic score, composed by Nino Rota, adds to the overall atmosphere, creating an indelible cinematic experience.One of the film's strengths is its character development. The audience witnesses the transformation of Michael Corleone, portrayed by Al Pacino, from a reluctant outsider to a ruthless and strategic leader. Pacino's performance is a tour de force, capturing the internal conflict and moral descent of his character with nuance and intensity.The supporting cast, including James Caan as the impulsive Sonny Corleone and Robert Duvall as the loyal Tom Hagen, delivers exceptional performances that contribute to the film's depth and authenticity. The ensemble cast, coupled with the screenplay by Coppola and Puzo, creates a narrative tapestry that weaves together the personal and professional lives of the characters."The Godfather" is notable for its meticulous attention to detail. From the costumes to the set design, every element contributes to the film's immersive quality. The use of symbolism, such as the recurring motif of oranges symbolizing impending death, adds layers of meaning to the narrative.The film explores themes of loyalty, betrayal, and the consequences of a life steeped in crime. The intricate plot is driven by the characters' relationships and the power struggles within the family and the broader organized crime syndicate. The moral ambiguity of the characters adds complexity to the narrative, forcing the audience to grapple with their own ethical judgments.Beyond its narrative and technical achievements, "The Godfather" has had a profound cultural impact. Phrases like "I'll make him an offer he can't refuse" have become iconic, and the film's influence can be seen in countless works that followed. It is a film that transcends its genre, leaving an indelible mark on the history of cinema.In conclusion, "The Godfather" is a cinematic triumph that continues to resonate with audiences decades after its release. With its compelling characters, masterful storytelling, and unforgettable performances, the film stands as a testament to the enduring power of storytelling through the medium of film. Whether one is a fan of crime dramas or simply appreciates the art of filmmaking, "The Godfather" remains a must-watch classic that has earned its place in the pantheon of great cinema.

title: I don't get it
content: I've got a masters in Criminology, and have studied filmography, and I just don't get it.  This isn't a great movie.  The only thing that could make it a classic is the quality of the actors that were hired - and while the actors themselves can and have made quality movies, this one just doesn't do it for me.  Brando didn't impress me in the least in this movie.And as for the portrayal of organized crime - nothing personal, but if you find it attractive to honor men who not just break the law but flout the laws of civilization, then more power to you.  Crime and criminals aren't glamorous - they're a sore on the backside of humanity that should be expunged.

title: An absolute masterpiece
content: "The Godfather" is a masterclass in storytelling that delves deep into the intricate dynamics of human nature. At its core, the film brilliantly captures the essence of personal connections and the emotional complexities tied to the concept of family. Through the Corleone saga, it unveils the profound significance of loyalty, bonds, and tradition within the clan, portraying the love and unity that define their existence.However, beneath this familial façade lies a poignant portrayal of the high costs incurred in the relentless quest for power. The movie astutely demonstrates the contradictions within us, showcasing the dichotomy between the tender love for family and the brutal, self-serving nature that comes with the pursuit of dominance.The film serves as a mirror reflecting our dualities-our innate desire for closeness and protection juxtaposed against our capacity for ruthless ambition and cruelty. It's a poignant reminder of the intricate balance between love, ambition, and the often harrowing consequences of choices made in the name of power.Overall, "The Godfather" doesn't just narrate a mafia tale; it subtly reveals the intricate web of human emotions and desires, painting a vivid portrait of the human condition where the pursuit of power and the love for family collide, leaving an indelible mark on both the characters and the audience.

title: Extraordinary Film
content: I have dissected this film, piece by piece. This is a film that can be seen several times, and each time, you take something else from the film. It's incredibly difficult to digest all of the beautiful layers that make The Godfather so special. There are thousands of films out there that are cut-n-dry. Basically, what u see is what u get....no less, no more. While, if u don't have an understanding of organized crime and its origin, u will most likely overlook the remarkable accuracy of the film. The life that is portrayed in The Godfather was very real, for many many years. However, as yrs went by, organized crime families, in America, began slowly straying from their core values...i.e., family, "Omerta" (code of silence), secrecy, respect, loyalty, etc. The Godfather illustrates life in the mafia during the 1st half of the 20th Century, where as a film like Goodfellas, shows mafia life during the 2nd half of the 20th Century. The Godfather is a film loaded w legendary actors who perform a script that's full of substance & grace, both, written & directed, by the great Francis Ford Coppola. Movies like, The Godfather, come around only a handful of times during a lifetime. Cinematic masterpiece.

title: The Godfather

title: Best of all
content: Definitely a classic. It never gets old! True, The Godfather is a little slow-moving and the plot takes a while to unfold, but neither of these are flaws as such. The slow pacing added to the elegiac quality The Godfather has, and as for the plot what is special about this plot is that it is very unpredictable because you have next to no idea where it is next going to take you. Being 18, I was worried whether I was old enough to appreciate this film or even understand it, but luckily I understood it perfectly, and I can well and truly appreciate it for the masterpiece it is considered to be. Must see.

title: Overrated to the extent that perhaps makes me underrate it
content: This film is long and dull. As a result of the first it is dull for very long periods, which is why this film warrants no more than a miserly 1/10. The acting is competent but no more and I must confess I lost my focus towards the end due to the quite shocking lack of entertainment that can be attributed to a poor script, lacklustre direction and a plot which leaves a lot to be desired. People say Godfather is rare in that its sequel improves upon it, but that isn't hard. Al Pacino gained a big reputation from this one and I am left bemused as to why, and this unfortunate idea has meant Pacino, a mediocre actor at best has been able to infiltrate our cinema screens on far too many occasions with a distinct lack of passion or charisma in any role he displays.

title: Be sure to give this movie the respect it deserves
content: Don Vito Corleone (Marlon Brando) is the head of a Mafia family. Sonny (James Caan) is his eldest and heir apparent. Michael (Al Pacino) is a return WWIl hero and wants to keep out of the family business. The Don refuses to go into the drug business which precipitate a mob war.There's no doubt that this is one of the greatest movie of all times. Director Francis Ford Coppola has crafted a masterpiece from Mario Puzo's novel. It's not just a great story, but great characters and great actors playing them. Forty years later, it's still as compelling as ever. The pacing is slower than today's standard, but it packs a punch more potent than anything recent. The acting power alone is incredible. When you consider that Al Pacino is the new unknown kid, the cast is unquestionable the best that Hollywood has to offer in that era. Every 10 minutes, there is an iconic scene. There's no way I can list them all.I rarely give a 10. Rarer still do I give it with no reservation. A perfect movie is not enough. It has to have cultural significance and some originality. That's 'The Godfather'. It's still being referenced today. May all the haters sleep with the fishes.

I love this kind of movies in which the protagonists or antagonists are complex beings, with ambitious and colossal ideas, and that not anyone could do. The conclusions of every act and decision that Don Corleone, or of his son, are amazing, doing all to the big, I consider at all of one of the best movies that I see in all my life, and I will never forgot the sound-track and the landscape, that is the final complement that does the movie unforgettable.

title: Great Movie
content: OSM movie all time biggest movie of mine. I think no movie can be compared to this one.I love this movie and all of the GF movies. I see something new every time I have seen it (countless, truly). The story of tragedy and (little) comedy that exists in this film is easily understood by people all over the world. This film has been called an American story however I have met others who have seen this movie in other languages and they seem to have the same love and appreciation for it that I do. I love the characters and all of the different personalities that they represent not just in families but in society itself. It seems like the entire cast is part of every other movie that I love as well. The sounds, music, color and light in the film are just as much a part of the film as the people. This could be attributed to the method in which it was filmed. At many parts of the film I can still find myself feeling the emotions conveyed in the film. I never tire of appreciating this film. I thank God that FFC is an American treasure. We are fortunate to have him.

title: As Good As It Gets
content: Maybe it's Marlon Brando. Maybe it's the score, cinematography, or the memorable characters, but there's just something about the Godfather that sticks with you. It's one of those movies that gets loved more and more as time goes on. It's one of those movie's you wish you could watch again for the first time. It's a movie in everyone top ten. It's a movie I'll be showing my kids. The Godfathers a journey of a reluctant son becoming the thing he swore he'd never become. A businessman, a killer, a Criminal. The Godfather is, without a doubt, one of the most well crafted cinematic masterpieces of all time.

title: Timeless epic!
content: The Godfather is a cinematic masterpiece that stands as one of the greatest films ever made. What sets The Godfather apart is its meticulous storytelling and rich character development. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Don Vito Corleone is iconic, exuding a calm yet menacing presence that captures the essence of a powerful mafia don. Al Pacino's transformation from the reluctant Michael Corleone into a ruthless leader is nothing short of brilliant, showcasing a complex and tragic character arc. Every scene is meticulously crafted, every line of dialogue carries weight, and every performance is memorable. The film's pacing, structure, and attention to detail make it a masterclass in filmmaking.In conclusion, this movie is more than just a crime drama; it is an epic tale of family, power, and the dark consequences of ambition. It remains a benchmark in the history of cinema, with its influence still felt in films today.

title: The Godfather trilogy was a highly successful film

I love this movie

title: superb movie
content: This film captivates audiences by immersing them in an underworld that exists right under our noses. Coppola skillfully places us in the midst of a society created by and for criminals, where cold-blooded murderers and seemingly honorable men coexist. The film delves into the Corleone family, led by Don Vito Corleone, portrayed by Marlon Brando. Don Vito, while occupying a unique position on the edge of this world, struggles to reconcile his moral principles with the reality of his surroundings. One particularly memorable scene takes place during his daughter's wedding, where his associate, Luca Brasi, rehearses a speech to be delivered to the Don. This scene showcases a humorous and endearing interaction between the two characters, evoking unexpected sympathy for these mobsters. It is worth noting that Lenny Montana, who played Luca Brasi, was an actual former mob hit-man, adding an extra layer of authenticity to his performance.

title: Great movie with enduring influence on cinema and stereotypes
content: I honestly can't understand those who voted one star for this movie: probably they're trying to counter-balance the great number of 9 and 10 given by many viewers. This movie is complete, with very good actors, enchanting music and a nice plot. The behavior of the characters and their way of speaking is accurate, the atmosphere of the scenes set in Sicily is real and so is the portrait of a "famiglia" with that kind of activities. This movie is the "standard" for all the following movies about mafia and it created a collective imaginary about this subject like no other movie. Some parts may be a bit long, but if you start enjoying the moves, the glares and the dialogues of the characters you will like them just like the action parts. I don't know if this movie deserves to be #1 of all times but surely it's the best movie of the genre I've ever seen.

title: "The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that continues to stand the test of time.
content: "The Godfather" is a cinematic masterpiece that continues to stand the test of time. The film tells the story of the Corleone crime family, and the struggles they face in maintaining power and loyalty within their ranks. The themes of family, power, and betrayal are woven seamlessly into the plot, creating a truly engaging and emotionally resonant experience.The acting in the film is outstanding, with Marlon Brando delivering a powerful and iconic performance as patriarch Vito Corleone. The supporting cast, including Al Pacino, James Caan, and Robert Duvall, are all equally impressive.Francis Ford Coppola's direction is masterful, with a keen sense of pacing and a strong attention to detail. He creates a rich and immersive world that draws the viewer in and keeps them engaged throughout. The score by Nino Rota is hauntingly beautiful and adds to the film's overall atmosphere.The film's cinematography, production design, and special effects are all top-notch, creating a sense of realism that further immerses the viewer in the story. The editing is smooth and seamless, adding to the film's overall cohesiveness.In summary, "The Godfather" is a film that is not to be missed. With its strong themes, outstanding acting, masterful direction, and stunning technical aspects, it is truly a cinematic gem that has stood the test of time and continues to resonate with audiences today.

title: A Timeless Masterpiece of Cinema
content: The Godfather is a cinematic masterpiece that redefined the crime genre. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, it delivers a gripping narrative of power, loyalty, and family, centered around the Corleone dynasty. Marlon Brando's portrayal of Vito Corleone is legendary, while Al Pacino's transformation from Michael, the reluctant son, to a ruthless leader is mesmerizing. The screenplay, haunting score, and cinematography create an unforgettable experience. Every scene is crafted with perfection, making it one of the greatest films ever made. A must-watch for any cinephile, The Godfather stands as an enduring classic in film history.

title: An outstanding look at the mobster hierarchy
content: Francis Ford Coppola manages to execute one of the finest pieces of American cinema with the first of his three part saga, The Godfather.From the dialogue to the acting, this film excels in painting a gritty, realistic depiction of the mobster hierarchy, with one of the greatest pieces of acting in cinematic history with Marlon Brando's Don Vito Corleone.This film has already stood the test of time and is deservedly ranked as one of the greatest films of all time. A true masterpiece.I urge you if you have not yet checked out this film, what are you waiting for? It's a true hallmark of cinematic excellence and is undoubtedly one of the greatest films ever made, in my opinion.

title: Some liken the film to some kind of spiritual awakening
content: Some liken the film to some kind of spiritual awakening. Of course, some can go to a church or mosque to find enlightenment and Faith in humanity, but most places of worship are open only certain days or times. But when you need affirmation of the lasting bond of friendships that prevail over the most dire circumstances, Shawshank will give it to you. It makes grown men (like me) cry, still. I wonder whether Shawshank was truly meant for viewing in the privacy of the home, because it is a personal experience that really makes you look inward. Nominated for seven, this is the best film that never one a single Oscar.

title: The Godfather - A Timeless Masterpiece of Crime Cinema
content: The Godfather, directed by the legendary Francis Ford Coppola, is a cinematic gem that has etched its place in history as an unrivaled masterpiece. Released in 1972, this crime epic transcends time and stands as a shining example of exceptional storytelling, brilliant performances, and profound exploration of power, family, and the complexities of the human spirit.Based on the renowned novel by Mario Puzo, The Godfather pulls us into the alluring world of the Corleone crime family. Marlon Brando's iconic portrayal of Don Vito Corleone anchors the film, supported by an ensemble cast of remarkable actors including Al Pacino, James Caan, and Robert Duvall, who bring these captivating characters to life with unparalleled depth and nuance.What sets The Godfather apart is its meticulously crafted screenplay. It weaves an intricate tale of intricate relationships, clashing loyalties, and gripping power dynamics. The film explores the consequences of choices made within the realm of organized crime, while delving into themes of loyalty, honor, and the erosion of innocence.Visually, The Godfather is a feast for the eyes. The cinematography, characterized by its masterful use of shadows and evocative compositions, sets the mood and transports us to the heart of this underworld saga. Coppola's attention to detail in recreating the 1940s and 1950s era, from the costumes to the meticulously designed sets, adds an extra layer of authenticity to the viewing experience.The film's score, composed by the legendary Nino Rota, has become an integral part of its identity. The haunting melodies, accompanied by the unforgettable theme, further heighten the emotional impact of the story, punctuating moments of tension, tragedy, and triumph.Beyond its technical brilliance, The Godfather shines in its exploration of complex characters and their moral dilemmas. Each individual is meticulously developed, revealing their vulnerabilities, desires, and internal conflicts. From Michael Corleone's (Al Pacino) tragic transformation from an outsider to a reluctant leader, to the inner turmoil of Tom Hagen (Robert Duvall) torn between loyalty and conscience, the characters resonate deeply and leave an indelible mark.The Godfather's influence on popular culture is immeasurable. It has shaped the crime genre and inspired countless filmmakers, setting the benchmark for character-driven narratives and gritty storytelling. Its iconic quotes, such as "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse," have become ingrained in our collective consciousness.In summary, The Godfather remains an unparalleled cinematic achievement. Its gripping narrative, impeccable performances, and profound examination of power and family dynamics continue to captivate audiences across generations. As a testament to the art of storytelling and the enduring impact of exceptional filmmaking, The Godfather holds its rightful place as a timeless masterpiece in the annals of cinema, one f those movies that makes you become the character, yes I wanted to be a mafia gangster after watching it !

title: The Definition Of  A Movie (The Godfather)
content: There is only one movie, one movie that stands out in my mind when I think cinema. It Is...The Godfather. Its The Movie you can watch many times and still find something new you didin't notice your previous viewings. Its the movie where you can learn more about the characters every moment of the film. Its the movie that shows the true 1940's mafia. It is the definition of a movie.Whether its the astonishing script, the incredible cast, and the amazing acting, you'll find something you'll like in this movie. Even if you hated this movie and disposes it, you can always say 1 thing you liked about it, at least 1 thing. As for the acting, Marlon Brando does one of the most memorable performances in the history of film-making. He plays the role of Vito Corleone, the head of one of the five families in New York City. He has 3 influential and historical actors as his son's. Michael being Al Pacino's part, plays his son, a young boy who just returned from world war II, not wanting anything to do with the family. Second, being the infamous James Caan, playing the hot headed Sonny, wanting to take over the family business when vito passes. Then There is Fredo, the poor, dimwitted, fredo, played by John Cazale.Along with the cast is Robert Duvall as Tom Hagen, the adopted son into the family, with irish blood at heart. Diane Keaton also does a fantastic job as a young woman dating Michael, not knowing what to expect.The Movie provides something everyone will enjoy, if its the violence you like, you have a lot of it. If its intriguing storyline, bada bing...you have it. Or if you just want to see a nice cast, and one of the best movies ever made....You have it. There is no doubt that this movie will remain in your head after you see it, and its spawned many fans from all over the world. Its a tearjerker, a noir, a love story, and a movie about the mafia. As I have said before, It is the definition of a Movie.A 12/10 rating A++++

title: the actuality of American dream........
content: I saw this movie because of my father's recommendation. It was just a dramatical movie at first. The perfect revenge and the movie which is for all of gangsters. But, when I saw this movie again, I felt some other parts. Widely, there are two themes in the movie; one is about American dream and the other one is about many life of mafia. The last son of Don Colione, Michael doesn't want to join his father's business. But, after Don got hurt by other mafia's gangsters, the Don family came to be in danger. He couldn't help but assist them. And he finally realized his destiny and his family's fate. He became the leader of the family. He was as good as his father and his cruelty was better than his father. Finally, he became the best godfather in the mafia and he lost his old shape. Michael's father, Vito shows American dream's reality in the movie. Before he dies, he grows many vegetables that he wanted. He wanted to live normally, but he became a gangster as if his son. For his death and Michael's victory between family fighting, the movie continues the darkness of the society and bad side of American dream.

title: Trust me when I say this film has earned its reputation
content: It's very easy to let high expectations get the better of you when you watch a film. Maybe the film is perfectly fine, but nowhere near as good as you had expected, and so you are left with a bitter taste in your mouth when sans these expectations you would have had a fine few hours (looking at you, Once Upon a Time in Hollywood). Or maybe your expectations are simply too high for any film to realistically meet. The Godfather could have easily fallen into one of these two categories. After all, when it comes to films that carry high expectations, it's hard to top The Godfather. And yet, in spite of all that, the film is still a masterpiece that enthralled me for all 3 hours of its runtime. Trust me when I say this film is one of those classics that has earned its legendary reputation. Almost everything about in this film is done to great effect. Even things I don't usually notice (unless they're really bad) like the editing and the sound design are done masterfully, the score is not only beautiful but the film knows when not to use the score and let the tension build, and of course you can't talk about The Godfather without talking about the legendary director and cast. With Francis Ford Coppola at the helm of Marlon Brando, Al Pacino, Robert Duval, James Caan, John Cazle and Diane Keaton, and an amazing story on top of that it really shouldn't surprise anyone this film is as good as it is. There are so many more things I could say to sing this films praises, and so many more things that deserve praise, so many amazing scenes and so many memorable moments/lines, but really, you should just see the film yourself.10/10

title: Winner!
content: The godfather is one of the greatest movies ever put together. Francis Coppola directed it in 1972 and integrated brilliant costumes, dynamic plot, detailed set, emotional sound track, and amazing actors involved in every scene the movie was one of the greatest successes of it's time and continues to remain a classic. I was born in 1990 and even though much as changed from when this movie was created to now, it is still a movie I can watch, enjoy, and appreciate because all those things listed above were spot on. This movie falls into multiple genres. Of those the largest is Crime Fiction. This genre crime fiction is the literary genre that fictionalizes crimes, their detection, criminals and their motives.The costumes not only fit the time in which the movie was set for, but as each set ventured from one location to another they matched the costumes with the location and each scene appropriately. Additionally each character seemed to have their own sort of style they displayed through these costumes. If each character looked and sounded the same, a viewer could easily guess the character by the clothing they wore.The plot engages the movie beautifully. From the beginning to end it leaves the viewer having a very direct and excellent understanding of what is happening and how it ties in to the main story. Even through watching the movie multiple times and knowing what happens I can still avoid anticipating what will happen next because it is so well established and drawn out.Matching costumes, characters are captured in beautiful and well constructed sets. Viewers can actually watch the movie and though have never been to where the movie takes place, they are able to visualize and understand exactly where they are. This movie does an excellent job at not just focusing on where the action is but showing a larger portion of the picture to allow viewers to fill in any additional puzzle pieces that normally aren't formed but in some cases with some viewers is absolutely necessary to understand exactly where they are in each scene.The sound track is very emotional. The symphony sound texture to the music allows background music to be applied to a scene and assist viewers to visualize what is going on and the emotions to be expected while the scene unfolds without requiring the use of additional vocals. This is exceptionally beneficial at the beginning and ending of each scene, as it displays the mood of the scene as it starts out or leaves a lasting effect of whatever just took place.Last but not least the actors are the people who made the film what it was. Each role was very specific to the actor and very distinguished from one to another. In specific, the Don's sons Michael and Sonny, were extreme opposites. While one was very calm and easy going the other was very hot headed and gung hoe, looking for action and death to those who disagreed with him or stood up to the other family members.All in all the movie was wonderful from beginning to end ultimately I would not change a single thing or think something could have been done to better the film. I definitely recommend anyone who has not watched this movie already to check it out!

title: No one can beat it. one cult classic movie ever
content: The Godfather is a 1972 American crime film directed by Francis Ford Coppola and produced by Albert S. Ruddy, based on Mario Puzo's best-selling novel of the same name. It stars Marlon Brando and Al Pacino as the leaders of a fictional New York crime family. The story, spanning 1945 to 1955, chronicles the family under the patriarch Vito Corleone, focusing on the transformation of Michael Corleone (Pacino) from reluctant family outsider to ruthless Mafia boss.Paramount Pictures obtained the rights to the novel before it gained popularity for the price of $80,000. Studio executives had trouble finding a director, as their first few candidates turned down the position. They and Coppola disagreed over who would play several characters, in particular Vito and Michael. Filming was done on location and completed earlier than scheduled. The musical score was composed primarily by Nino Rota with additional pieces by Carmine Coppola.The film was the highest-grossing film of 1972 and was for a time the highest-grossing film ever made. It won the Oscars for Best Picture, Best Actor (Brando) and Best Adapted Screenplay (for Puzo and Coppola). Its seven other Oscar nominations included Pacino, James Caan, and Robert Duvall for Best Supporting Actor and Coppola for Best Director. It was followed by sequels The Godfather Part II (1974) and Part III (1990).The Godfather is widely regarded as one of the greatest films in world cinema and one of the most influential, especially in the gangster genre. It was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry in 1990 and is ranked the second-greatest film in American cinema (behind Citizen Kane) by the American Film Institute.

title: Immense film but about disgusting characters
content: The fabulous opening shot and scene immediately establish the spirit and essence of things. "I've spent my life trying not to be careless. Women and children can be careless, but not men", says Vito Corleone. It's a great film, an immense narrative that stretches effortlessly over nearly three hours.But nothing is truer than when Connie calls her brother Michael, Vito's son, a "lousy cold-hearted b...rd." That's what he is, a cold, heartless killer, a liar with no morals, a snake. That's the limit of the film, absolutely impressive in its narration and direction but giving life to repulsive characters.

title: "The Offer" TV series compelled me to finally watch "The Godfather"
content: Now I love movies in general, but somehow the so-called masterpiece "The Godfather" from 1972 has not appealed to me enough to sit through the darkly-lit, three-hour running time. However, I hear great things about "The Offer" which is about the making of "The Godfather," so I decide to invest ten minutes of my time to see what this series is about. It is indeed a well-made show, with a good story, and I end up watching all episodes. So now in 2023 I just have to watch "The Godfather." I can see why this movie would be considered a classic for its time. It has interesting, brooding shots, cast with powerhouse actors, some not yet famous at the time but have since become huge celebrities in their own right. I do have issues with the movie's slow pace, some campy acting from supporting actors, like a couple of mafia sidekicks and the father of the bride in Sicily, awkward fade transitions between scenes, and some rather disjointed turn of events. But all of that is forgiven now that I have discovered the gem that is Al Pacino. I have watched a few of his later movies when he is already considered a legendary actor, but nothing has tickled my fancy until seeing him as a young, very handsome Pacino in "The Godfather," who can convey a million emotions just from his piercing thoughtful gaze. "The Offer" is correct; you cannot take your eyes off Pacino as Michael Corleone in "The Godfather," even as you witness his gradual moral deterioration. For this, I give this "classic" 8 stars in 2023.

title: One of the best movie of all time
content: It can really be considered one of the best movies of all time. The cast is simply amazing, stellar. Al Pacino, Marlon Brando, Robert de Niro, Diane Keaton, James Caan and many others gathered all together at their most young ages in this masterpiece. The acting is insanely high quality and all of the actors cooperate to create one of the best choral performance of all time. Marlon Brandon is simply amazing, really beyond. The way in which he modulates his voice for the whole duration of the movie and his mouth position gives to the character such a specific personality which could be enough to make the movie itself. Al Pacino, who fought so hard for this part, is simply perfect for the role of the son. It's just incredible the depth and the courage with which he carries his performance for the whole duration of the movie, especially the way he shifts his believes. Remarkable how he works on the evolution of the character. Not to mention the sweat and amazingly talented Diane Keaton, who is just perfect for her role as well mannered girlfriend and later wife of Al Pacino. I couldn't recommend it more. It's one of these movies with an eternal energy; one of these movies people continue watching and watching all over again because of all the shades and other details which you continue discover and discover every time more and better. Go and enjoy!

title: A Perfect Masterpiece By Its Definition
content: The Godfather (1972) 10/10!!!Yep, it is still perfect! My 4th viewing ✅ and my opinion hasn't changed one bit. I have actually notice a couple of new things that have made me appreciate the film even more! Quite frankly, it really ie insane just how good it is and how even 50 years later, it totally still holds up! A masterpiece of complete brilliance with genius storylines interconnected so beautifully ultimately making it super satisfying for audiences to connect the dots and really understand what's actually going on. The picture really showcases what life in the mafia is like and it is done with so much heart that you genuinely love and care about these characters as they are actually pretty relatable characters who often make a lot of sense, but yet are unfortunately born into a family full of crime! There are really not that many films out there that successfully manage to give the viewer an exciting and thrilling viewing experience, no matter how often they watch it. A real masterpiece by its definition filled with all-time great and iconic performances that essentially make up for an iconic, timeless classic that really has stood the test of time and presumably will be relevant! One of those films humanity can be proud of when looking back at pop cultural trends that have happened over time. Always a genuine privilege for me whenever I watch this beauty! 10/10.

title: A masterpiece of culture and anthropology
content: As an Qatari man watching this film for the first time in 2009, it struck me how much I got attached. More than four decades later, and a generation apart, and to a culture so distant from mine, and still this film strikes as one of the most memorable. What makes it that was the question that not only haunted me for years, but also pushed me to study filmmaking and dive intro the subject. This film has not only influenced my awareness and thinking, but ultimately my career and life.

title: Godfather is Amazing
content: The Godfather is an absolute "Classic". Both Al Pacino and Robert DeNero killed their roles. It's not often we get a movie with such in-depth detail as to why things happened the way they did. Politically correct in every "bad" way. I was very young when i first seen this movie and really didn't grasp the exact concept. Now, as an adult, it all makes sense. If anyone reading this has never seen this movie, I recommend you watch it and the others as well. It might even touch home with most that grew up in these neighborhoods and countries during the date allocated within the film. Film makers and anyone acting should make it an occupation to watch this film. Exciting, passionate, dramatic. These are the words I use to best describe my experience with watching this movie. It has also sparked my interest in making my own films. The action and originality of the film makes me want to create a movie just like this one in modern day times. Thank you Godfather, for you have given me much needed inspiration.

title: The Reviewfather
content: The Godfather has iconic status and a near-flawless execution. The film is a maste rclass in storytelling, with an ending that is not only memorable but deeply resonant. It maintains a consistent level of excellence throughout, with powerful performances, masterful direction, and a compelling narrative. While the initial pacing may feel slightly slow to some, it effectively sets the stage for the complex and gripping story that unfolds.The Godfather transcends mere entertainment, becoming a cultural touchstone. Its impact is undeniable, and its influence on cinema is immense. The film's ability to seamlessly blend character development, intricate plotting, and thematic depth makes it an enduring masterpiece. It's a film that needs much attention and rewards repeated viewings, revealing it's many layers. The slight initial pacing aside, it is an incredible film from start to finish.

title: Any description is not enough
content: Every character seems to be perfectly embedded, everyone has a specified reason to be in the plot and each one brings something substantial that makes us remember them. It is magnificent how the main characters show an ironic mix between honesty, respect, etc. and anger, betrayal and many other facets that makes us ask if they're good or bad people. Beyond a classification for the characters, you gonna love them as they are, and we can understand that there's more than just black and white. Definitely, a movie to watch, no matter how many years from his release, and no, I can't say that is a gangster movie, neither that is a Pacino's Movie, no no, It's more than that, The Godfather could be called for to many people like "The Movie".

title: amazing
content: amazing movie The Godfather is a 1972 American crime drama film directed by Francis Ford Coppola and produced by Albert S. Ruddy from a screenplay by Mario Puzo and Coppola. Starring Marlon Brando and Al Pacino as the leaders of the fictional Corleone New York crime family, the story spans the years 1945–55, concentrating on the transformation of Michael Corleone from reluctant family outsider to ruthless Mafia boss while chronicling the family under the patriarch Vito Based on Puzo's best-selling novel of the same name, The Godfather is widely regarded as one of the greatest films in world cinema[6]— and as one of the most influential, especially in the gangster genre.[7] The film ranks #1 on Empire magazine's 2008 list of the 500 greatest movies of all time.[8] Ranked second to Citizen Kane by the American Film Institute in 2007,[9] it was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry of the Library of Congress in 1990 as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".The film was the box office leader for 1972 and for a time, was the highest-grossing picture ever made. It won three Academy Awards for that year: Best Picture, Best Actor (Brando) and in the category Best Adapted Screenplay for Puzo and Coppola. Its nominations in seven other categories included Pacino, James Caan and Robert Duvall for Best Supporting Actor and Coppola for Best Director. The success spawned two sequels: The Godfather Part II in 1974, and The Godfather Part III in 1990.

title: i can not love this movie more
content: Theatrical as part of Paramount's re-release, I must say that knowing the film and story so closely allowed me to just sit back and enjoy what Coppola put on the screen. What really struck me is how there are so many reasons why this film shouldn't have worked yet everything came together so perfectly.Marlon Brando takes the showrunner role here, the patriarch who's past his prime, but it's easy to spot the real star of the piece: Al Pacino, who burns up the screen with sheer ferocity. Robert Duvall is easy to miss in a quieter part, but watch out for James Caan whose volatile Sonny is one of the film's most engaging characters.Altogether this is a splendid and unforgettable piece of film-making,

title: Review of "The Godfather" (1972)
content: Francis Ford Coppola's "The Godfather" (1972) stands as a cinematic masterpiece, an exemplar of storytelling, character development, and film direction. Adapted from Mario Puzo's best-selling novel, this film isn't just a chronicle of the mafia underworld but a deep exploration of power, family, and the American dream.At the heart of the film is the Corleone family, led by the patriarch Vito Corleone, masterfully played by Marlon Brando. Brando's portrayal is nothing short of iconic, embodying the complexities of a man who is at once a ruthless crime lord and a devoted family man. His raspy voice, deliberate gestures, and the way he cradles a cat in the opening sequence are indelibly etched in the minds of film aficionados.However, it's not just Brando that shines. The film is replete with remarkable performances. Al Pacino's portrayal of Michael Corleone, a young man initially resistant to the family business but eventually its most ruthless advocate, is a marvel of character transformation. His transition from an innocent war hero to the cold-blooded Don showcases Pacino's incredible range and depth as an actor.Cinematographically, "The Godfather" is a lesson in subtlety and nuance. Gordon Willis' dark and moody lighting, often referred to as "Rembrandt lighting", casts characters in shadows, perfectly capturing the murky moral universe they inhabit. The sepia tones used throughout offer a nostalgic hue, making it feel like a relic from a bygone era, and yet its themes remain timeless.The plot itself is an intricate web of familial bonds, betrayals, and power struggles, but it never feels convoluted. Instead, the tight narrative and compelling pacing keep viewers riveted. Scenes such as the iconic horse's head in the bed or Michael's restaurant assassination are unforgettable not just for their shock value, but for their narrative significance.Nino Rota's haunting score is another integral component, weaving together the film's emotional arcs. The melancholic trumpet solo that introduces the main theme is instantly recognizable, echoing the tragic undertones of the story.Yet, beyond the crime and violence, "The Godfather" fundamentally revolves around family. It emphasizes loyalty, tradition, and the lengths one might go to protect their own. This focus on family is what differentiates "The Godfather" from other crime dramas and what has resonated deeply with audiences across generations.Coppola's deft touch is evident throughout. He balances visceral sequences with quieter, introspective moments, allowing characters space to breathe and evolve. The wedding scene at the beginning, juxtaposed with Vito's meetings in his darkened office, is a perfect example of this balance - celebration and joy on one hand, and the murkiness of power deals on the other.In conclusion, "The Godfather" is not just a film; it's an experience, an immersion into a world that's both foreign and familiar. It's a tale of ambition, power, and family, masterfully woven together by Coppola and his team. Nearly half a century after its release, it remains as impactful and relevant as ever, a testament to its place in cinematic history.
